importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the most recent update on the flooding crisis, showing the ongoing impact and emergency response efforts in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred last week, establishing the temporal context of the disaster and the timing of the response efforts.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
Another 65 people are still missing, with significant numbers reported in Veracruz (43), Hidalgo (18), and Puebla (4).
The primary cause of the flooding was the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military personnel have been deployed, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, to deliver food, water, and support to affected areas.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some structures near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply for about 263,000 users who lost power.
Governors and federal authorities are coordinating relief efforts across the five affected states.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating the severity of the rainfall.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death and missing figures during a daily briefing with the President.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused catastrophic flooding across five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, damaging over 100,000 homes and cutting off access to many areas. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to provide emergency aid, including food and clean water. Authorities have restored over 80% of electricity to affected areas, and President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua emphasized the lack of prior meteorological warnings, raising concerns about early warning systems and disaster preparedness in Mexico.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
